Cycle Removal Group.

Detailed Description

This module contains the implementation of Cycle Removal service, i.e., converting a netlist into acyclic hypergraph. Many applications in EDA, such as finding the maximum delay path, request the input netlist be first temporarily converted to a acyclic graph. Typically, we obtain an acyclic digraph by reversing the directions of some pins.

(c.f. G. D. Battista., Graph Drawing: Algorithms for the Visualization of Graphs, Pentice Hall, Section 9.4.)

If is a digraph and , then we denote the digraph obtained by reversing all the edge of by . To remove cycles, we choose a set such that the digraph is acyclic. The main problem is how to choose so that is small.

A set of edges of a digraph is a feedback set, if is acyclic. The feedback set is closely related to the well-known feedback arc set, which is defined as a set of edges whose removal makes the digraph acyclic. The problem of finding a minimum cardinality feedback edge set of a given digraph is equivalent to the well-known feedback arc set problem. Unfortunately this problem is NP-complete. Thus effective heuristics are needed.

Suppose that we choose an ordering of the vertices of a digraph . We say that is a vertex sequence for . An edge with is called an leftward edge (with respect to ). In other words, if the vertices are drawn on a horizontal line in the left to right order as they appear in , then the leftward edges point to the left. The set of leftward edges for a vertex forms a feedback set. Conversely, if is a feedback set, then by computing a topological ordering of te digraph obtained by reversing all edges in , we obtain a vertex sequence, such that contains every leftward edge. Thus the feedback set problems is equivalent to finding a vertex sequence with as few leftward edges as possible.
